Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Towards Securing Visible Light Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to its many nice features such as license-free spectrum, abundant bandwidth, and Gbps-level transmission rate, visible light communication (VLC) has been considered to be a promising small-cell solution for alleviating the RF spectrum scarcity problem in the 5G era. While the research on VLC devices has made significant progress in recent years, the security aspect of VLC has not been well understood so far. Contrary to the initial common belief that VLC is intrinsically secure because the propagation of visible light is directive and can be confined within a closed space, recent studies have revealed that VLC is vulnerable to eavesdroppers that are outside of the direct beam of the light, or even outside the closed space and do not have direct line-of-sight (LOS) to the light source. Moreover, the special optical nature of visible light propagation also subjects VLC to other unique types of attacks, such as LOS blocking and spoofing. These attacks will constitute serious threats to VLC systems when they are deployed in large scale in the near future. This EAGER project aims to obtain a comprehensive and urgently-needed understanding on the security vulnerabilities of VLC, and to explore new knowledge on rigid and provably-secure physical-layer countermeasures.

This project will investigate the capability of visible light Multiple Input-Multiple Output (MIMO) in combatting VLC-specific attacks. In particular, a friendly-jamming-assisted visible light MIMO beamforming architecture is proposed to counter eavesdropping from unknown eavesdroppers, i.e., eavesdroppers of an unknown number and at unknown locations. This architecture is then extended by using more photodiodes (PDs) per user and accounting for the change of VLC channel state information, to effectively detect and mitigate blocking and spoofing attacks. The investigator will further study the blocking-resilience capacity of the multi-user VLC MIMO system to provide differential protection for users of different priorities. Moreover, a MIMO VLC testbed will be developed to evaluate the performance of the proposed solutions. The project will also carry out an integrated education plan to broaden its impact to the society, with a special emphasis on underrepresented and minority groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to its many nice features such as license-free spectrum, abundant bandwidth, and Gbps-level transmission rate, visible light communication (VLC) has been considered to be a promising small-cell solution for offloading traffic from the crowded RF spectrum in the 5G era. While the research on VLC devices has made significant progress in recent years, the security vulnerabilities of VLC has not been well understood so far. Contrary to the initial common belief that VLC is intrinsically secure because the propagation of visible light is directive and can be confined within a closed space, recent studies have revealed that VLC is vulnerable to eavesdroppers that are outside of the direct beam of the light, or even outside the closed space and do not have direct line-of-sight (LOS) to the light source. Moreover, the special optical nature of visible light propagation also renders VLC susceptible to other types of attacks, such as LOS blocking and spoofing. These attacks will constitute serious threats to VLC systems when they are deployed in large scale in the near future. This project aims to obtain a comprehensive and urgently-needed understanding on the security vulnerabilities of VLC, and to explore new knowledges on rigid and provably-secure physical-layer countermeasures.

The main intellectual merit outcomes of this project include:

1. A statistical framework has been proposed to model and characterize the confidentiality of indoor VLC systems by accounting for both specular and diffusive reflections in the VLC channel. A deep neural network model has been proposed to characterize the spatial distribution of VLC channel response, based on which the upper and the lower bounds of the VLC secrecy capacity are derived. Leveraging these bounds, the spatial distribution of the VLC secrecy capacity in a given indoor communication space is obtained, leading to insights on VLC?s vulnerability to eavesdroppings that are outside the direct beam of the light or do not have the line of sight.

2. We have proposed VL-Watchdog, a scalable and always-on signal-level spoofing detection framework, to protect VLC and VLS (visible light sensing) systems against spoofing attacks. VL-Watchdog has a MISO (multiple-input single-output) architecture and is based on redundant orthogonal encoding of the transmitted visible lights. VL-Watchdog can be implemented as a small hardware add-on to an existing VL system. Once deployed, the watchdog will persistently monitor the light signals in the field to ensure they are sent only from authentic (legitimate) transmitters (LEDs). VL-Watchdog is scalable and is capable of supporting large-scale VL systems, and does not assume any physical or optical difference in the LED hardware.

3. The value of target information in security attacks has been studied from a network economics perspective, when the target information can be traded between a data broker and multiple attackers. A novel multi-stage Stackelberg security game is formulated to characterize both the cooperative and competitive interactions of the data broker and attackers. The network-economic optimal behaviors of various participants of the security game are derived, including the attackers? competitive equilibrium solutions and data broker?s optimal pricing strategy. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous attackers are considered in this study.

The broader impact outcomes of this project include:

1. This project has significantly advanced the state of the art in the security of visible light systems. Following an inter-disciplinary research agenda and taking methods from signal processing, machine learning, game theory, optimization, network economics, communication, networking, and security, this project has obtained a comprehensive understanding on the security vulnerabilities of VLC, and has developed solid mathematical foundations that can be used to investigate and develop rigid and provably-secure countermeasures to these vulnerabilities. New knowledges on the security of VLC and VLS systems have been generated as a result of this project. The cross-disciplinary nature of this research has also enriched the studies in all related disciplines.

2. The research outcomes have been disseminated to the networking and security community via publications, talks, and posters. Some of the research results have been integrated into the course materials taught by the PI at the undergraduate and graduate levels. This project has also been introduced to many high-school students at E-days of the Auburn University. This helps to foster the high-school students' interests in taking science and technology as their future career.

3. This project has supported several Ph.D. students, including one female student. Through this project, they have received rigid training in game theory, signal processing, machine learning, optimization, wireless networking, and cyber security. In addition, they have also acquired hands-on experience in the simulation and testbed development. The above training and hands-on experience will lay a solid foundation for their future career development.
